relationships.evidence_text: Welcome to the Y on Earth Community Podcast. I'm your host, Aaron William Perry.
we're visiting with Dr. Robert Klonenger.
Dr. Robert Klonenger is director of the Anthropedia Institute.

relationships.evidence_text: The Anthropedia Institute is the research and advisory component of the Anthropedia Foundation.
a nonprofit organization dedicated to development of human well-being through initiatives and healthcare and education.
He is widely cited and honored for his innovative biopsychosocial research.

and Personality and Psychopathology by American Psychiatric Press.
clearly you've been not only well recognized by the global community for your work.
you're in the top two hundred or something like that, around 180.
your science, which really is avant-garde cutting edge science.
the work you're doing through anthropemia and elsewhere is from my perspective, one of the most important leading edges of the kind of work, the healing work, and the creative work.
human beings are largely responsible for the impact on the environment that is causing these problems.
what it is about our human nature that may have led us to get to this situation.

to live sustainably.
what is it that's going wrong?
that's why I developed personality inventories.
tried to validate those to show just what it is that makes up a healthy person.
we had good ways to measure human health and well-being, the physical, mental, the spiritual, social components of health.
what was it that led to the evolution of our capacity to be creative.
that has been the task I set for myself.
you've covered so much deep and complex scientific research.
we're going to include a handful of articles in the show notes.
a piece that you wrote in 2013 called What Makes People Healthy, Happy and Fulfilled in the Face of Current World Challenges.
some critical aspects of ourselves as individual humans. And how that has an impact and influence on our complex social interactions.
three key attributes, self-directedness, cooperativesness, and self-transcendence as critical to understanding perhaps our own individual development.
human personality actually involves two domains. One is our temperament.
our emotional drives like to look out for danger, which I call harmit winds, to be interested in things that are unusual, new, complex, which I call novelty seeking.
these are what create our habits and our attachments and our desires.
we share temperament.
we have evolved to other systems of learning and memory that give us an ability to control our emotions.
being self-aware and being able to use our awareness to consider the value that achieving a goal may have.
we are different from chimpanzees and our other ancestors, because although we share temperament, we have evolved to other systems of learning and memory.

If we make our habits consistent with our goals and our values

that means that you're purposeful and resourceful, and you're also willing to take responsibility to get things done
if you're cooperative, you're tolerant and helpful and empathic

we are both self-directed and cooperative, but we add to what you see with just logical reasoning and analysis

look around at the wealthiest executives and people with a lot of influence and they're often still very unsatisfied with their lives.
they begin to question whether their values are really satisfying.
they thought that if they achieved money and power and so on, that they would be fulfilled and satisfied.

We set out to identify all the genes for human personality.
we found that there are about a thousand of them and they interact with each other in very complex ways.
what distinguishes us from chimpanzees and even from the other hominids is this capacity for self-transcendence.

it turns out that we actually evolved, became human, but modern humans with creativity in the sense of community and an imagination for how to get along with each other.
That happened in response to climatic changes that were threatening our very survival.
the capacity to be creative in communal and self-transcendent goes back only a hundred thousand years.

until we realized it is not an inexhaustible resource.

relationships.evidence_text: A culture that is so infused with and permeated with an ethos stemming from a super underdeveloped self transcendence.
many, if not most, of the corporate leaders over the last several decades...generally have underdeveloped self transcendence attributes.
the current sort of business philosophy that emphasizes profit without a sense of social responsibility.
that thinks like Hayek said that social justice is just an illusion.
it's simply not consistent with our human nature.

You know we have things where people are doing physical exercise that stimulate both their strong and their weak muscles...
But other things that help with detoxification, relaxation, meditation...
And so we put together things that address the body, the mind and the soul simultaneously.
Because if you don't have a sense of what you value, what's good, what's virtuous, and you don't have the capacity for change...

And it leads me to think about, you know, some of the serendipity that can occur in our lives.
...how do those who are already well on the road of a cultural creative development as an individual, how do we accelerate that work?

people who recognize this need for social justice, for sustainability, for love, hope, and faith, and all of our actions will have a sense of unity.

we have to not make the mistake of lacking compassion and respect for people who have different values.
keeping communication bridges open to be really there to help everyone.
try to practice being tolerant and being ready to help them when they have trouble.
don't demonize people who are currently maybe living in a way that we might think is unhealthy.
we have to first help those who are like-minded to work together as we're doing here.
we really all do have talents and abilities that would work much better if we helped one another.
if we maintain respectful dialogue with them and try to practice being tolerant.
given many of these very near-term systemic complex challenges that we're facing.
we need to, you know, mobilize as many of us as we possibly can.
a little bit like the question that was asked of Gandhi, that, you know, he said he would always do what's right in his opinion.
that unity, while it should look out certainly for those people who culturally creative, but also for all the younger generation.
